issue.title: prometheus_sd_discovered_targets showing a deleted service
issue.body: ### What did you do? Created a serviceMonitor and service in a k8s namespace. The serviceMonitor was misconfigured, but was still picked up by Prometheus and `prometheus_sd_discovered_targets == 0`. I then deleted the service and serviceMonitor, but the metric was still reporting. This was after 12 hours of the service and serviceMonitor not existing anymore. ### What did you expect to see? I expect to see a deleted service not be picked up by `prometheus_sd_discovered_targets` at some point after deletion. ### What did you see instead? Under which circumstances? I saw `prometheus_sd_discovered_targets == 0` returning metrics for a service that was deleted many hours before. I did not see the service in the Service Discovery UI, so seems like the metric was only affected. ### System information Linux 5.10.147+ x86_64 ### Prometheus version ```text prometheus, version 2.40.5 (branch: HEAD, revision: 44af4716c86138869aa621737139e6dacf0e2550) build user: root@70f803b28803 build date: 20221201-12:50:06 go version: go1.19.3 platform: linux/amd64 ``` ### Prometheus configuration file _No response_ ### Alertmanager version _No response_ ### Alertmanager configuration file _No response_ ### Logs _No response_

comment.body:
I had the same issue with an podmonitor after deleting it.
The target was successfully removed from the k8s and also from the prometheus but the metric still had it inside.

issue.title: Running out of disk space resulted in unrecoverable WAL error
issue.body:
### What did you do?

Ran Prometheus

### What did you expect to see?

Out-of-disk errors should cause temporary loss of data but not a fatal condition I have to log in and delete the WAL to fix.



### What did you see instead? Under which circumstances?

The disk filled up, and the first report of this was from the WAL:

```
ts=2023-10-23T23:11:06.646Z caller=scrape.go:1359 level=error component="scrape manager" scrape_pool=kube-system/cadvisor target=https://kubernetes.default.svc.cluster.local.:443/api/v1/nodes/gke-dev-redacted/proxy/metrics/cadvisor msg="Scrape commit failed" err="write to WAL: log samples: write /prometheus/data/wal/00006644: no space left on device"
ts=2023-10-23T23:11:06.704Z caller=scrape.go:1359 level=error component="scrape manager" scrape_pool=kubernetes-pods target=http://10.132.15.32:9150/metrics msg="Scrape commit failed" err="write to WAL: log samples: write /prometheus/data/wal/00006644: no space left on device"
...
ts=2023-10-23T23:11:08.474Z caller=scrape.go:1359 level=error component="scrape manager" scrape_pool=kube-system/kubelet target=https://kubernetes.default.svc.cluster.local.:443/api/v1/nodes/gke-dev-redacted/proxy/metrics msg="Scrape commit failed" err="write to WAL: log samples: write /prometheus/data/wal/00006644: no space left on device"
```

After this point apparently something was cleaned up on the disk (I didn't do it), because those errors stop.
Then remote-write reports it can't read that segment:
```
ts=2023-10-23T23:13:40.683Z caller=dedupe.go:112 component=remote level=error remote_name=some_remote_write url=https://example.com:1234/prometheus msg="error tailing WAL" err="segment 6644: unexpected full record: unexpected full record"
```

Now we get a flood of these, various ref numbers, presumably because those series were in the lost WAL segment:
```
ts=2023-10-23T23:14:06.048Z caller=dedupe.go:112 component=remote level=info remote_name=some_remote_write url=https://example.com:1234/prometheus msg="Dropped sample for series that was not explicitly dropped via relabelling" ref=56218783
```

Subsequently, the WAL cannot be truncated:
```
ts=2023-10-24T01:02:11.908Z caller=checkpoint.go:101 level=info component=tsdb msg="Creating checkpoint" from_segment=6625 to_segment=6656 mint=1698105600000
ts=2023-10-24T01:03:02.735Z caller=db.go:984 level=error component=tsdb msg="compaction failed" err="WAL truncation in Compact: create checkpoint: read segments: corruption in segment /prometheus/data/wal/00006644 at 61899498: unexpected full record"
```

This error repeats every 2 hours.  The WAL continues to grow.



### System information

Linux 5.15.107+ x86_64

### Prometheus version

```text
I built this Prometheus myself; it's a few commits on from 624b973eb.
```


### Prometheus configuration file

_No response_

### Alertmanager version

_No response_

### Alertmanager configuration file

_No response_

### Logs

```text
See log excerpts above.
```

comment.body:
I’m broadly in agreement, but I do think if the disk gets some more space it would be reasonable for Prometheus to recover without further administrator action. 
Perhaps a restart.

issue.title: Scraping: Optionally use SHA for series cache keys
issue.body:
Controlled by `--enable-feature=scrape-cache-sha`.

Prometheus has a cache to speed up recognition of metrics in scrape results, including samples dropped by relabeling rules. This setting changes the keys from the whole string to a 32-byte checksum. 

This consumes a lot less memory, at the cost of ~15% extra CPU and possible hash collisions. By "birthday problem" math the risk is about 1 in 2^128, or basically never.

A SHA512/256 value is 32 bytes, compared to a metrics string at some hundreds of bytes.
Benefit is biggest if you have a lot of dropped series, as described at #12443

We have two sets of maps so in the SHA case we can use a fixed-size byte array as the key and save a 16 byte string header; this does make the code a little uglier. Also `droppedSeriesSHA` contains `uint64` rather than `*uint64` which saves another 8 bytes, at the cost of an extra hash of the key each time it is looked up, which is quite cheap.

Included are a couple of refactors, one which takes hundreds of lines of boilerplate out of scraping tests.

Example results from profiling a Prometheus scraping ~2 million metrics, 500,000 of which are dropped:
Before:
```
  386.01MB  9.39% 43.02%   386.01MB  9.39%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addRef
  260.94MB  6.35% 56.87%   260.94MB  6.35%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addDropped
```
After:
```
  190.36MB  4.70% 62.52%   190.36MB  4.70%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addRefSHA 
   63.34MB  1.56% 90.51%    63.34MB  1.56%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addDroppedSHA 
```

comment.body:
Ok that doesn’t make any sense. 
I stared at the code for a long time to decide it was true, but it isn’t. I stand by the statement that it is confusing. 

This is where caches are created per-loop, ie per target:

https://github.com/prometheus/prometheus/blob/main/scrape/scrape.go#L287

issue.title: Scraping: Optionally use SHA for series cache keys
issue.body:
Controlled by `--enable-feature=scrape-cache-sha`.

Prometheus has a cache to speed up recognition of metrics in scrape results, including samples dropped by relabeling rules. This setting changes the keys from the whole string to a 32-byte checksum. 

This consumes a lot less memory, at the cost of ~15% extra CPU and possible hash collisions. By "birthday problem" math the risk is about 1 in 2^128, or basically never.

A SHA512/256 value is 32 bytes, compared to a metrics string at some hundreds of bytes.
Benefit is biggest if you have a lot of dropped series, as described at #12443

We have two sets of maps so in the SHA case we can use a fixed-size byte array as the key and save a 16 byte string header; this does make the code a little uglier. Also `droppedSeriesSHA` contains `uint64` rather than `*uint64` which saves another 8 bytes, at the cost of an extra hash of the key each time it is looked up, which is quite cheap.

Included are a couple of refactors, one which takes hundreds of lines of boilerplate out of scraping tests.

Example results from profiling a Prometheus scraping ~2 million metrics, 500,000 of which are dropped:
Before:
```
  386.01MB  9.39% 43.02%   386.01MB  9.39%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addRef
  260.94MB  6.35% 56.87%   260.94MB  6.35%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addDropped
```
After:
```
  190.36MB  4.70% 62.52%   190.36MB  4.70%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addRefSHA 
   63.34MB  1.56% 90.51%    63.34MB  1.56%  github.com/prometheus/prometheus/scrape.(*scrapeCache).addDroppedSHA 
```

comment.body:
> the scrape cache is bound to a single target

Scrape cache is shared across many targets; at least everything in a pool (which corresponds to a job). 

It’s a bit complicated, eg if you change config you get a new cache.

issue.title: Discrepancy between reported series and series present in the block
issue.body:
### What did you do?

We had an OOM kill and to my surprise we basically duplicated in the amount of series. See screenshot: 
![image](https://github.com/prometheus/prometheus/assets/5786097/acf4dcac-57d2-406a-8e59-098e8c26288b)

I was investigating it, and obviously when turning around some stones I found some things we could improve on. However, when I dug further, checking the blocks themselves, I notice a different number in the amount of series:

```
promtool tsdb list .
BLOCK ULID                  MIN TIME       MAX TIME       DURATION     NUM SAMPLES  NUM CHUNKS   NUM SERIES   SIZE
01HCT4FHKH8CFEDS0VDRJCYPJY  1697378400000  1697385600000  2h0m0s       4440544312   37409715     10168069     7768846944
01HCTBB8VPR9CNZPGXVXPG2956  1697385600000  1697392800000  2h0m0s       4470131819   37641991     10216217     7825614680
01HCTJ703HY5QYW9SM1C2WM456  1697392800000  1697400000000  2h0m0s       4475921724   37603353     10122896     7821507631
01HCTS2QBN3ZVJDSYDBD687TZR  1697400000000  1697407200000  2h0m0s       4482466962   37737103     10214242     7802420218
```

So, I'm seeing:

- UI /tsdb-status reports:  Number of Series = 18922003
- prometheus_tsdb_head_series metric, reports roughly the same ^ 18m
- `count({__name__=~".+"})` = 8904164 (almost half)
- tsdb list, see above (they are somewhat older blocks, but are somewhat equal to the reported count query)






### What did you expect to see?

That the metric & the API would report roughly the same amount of series as what the blocks reports

### What did you see instead? Under which circumstances?

...

### System information

Docker image

### Prometheus version

```text
v2.44.0
```


### Prometheus configuration file

```yaml
args


      --web.console.templates=/etc/prometheus/consoles
      --web.console.libraries=/etc/prometheus/console_libraries
      --config.file=/etc/prometheus/config_out/prometheus.env.yaml
      --web.enable-lifecycle
      --web.enable-remote-write-receiver
      --enable-feature=memory-snapshot-on-shutdown
      --web.external-url=https://redacted/prometheus
      --web.route-prefix=/prometheus
      --storage.tsdb.wal-compression
      --storage.tsdb.retention.time=30d
      --storage.tsdb.retention.size=224000MB
      --storage.tsdb.path=/prometheus
      --web.enable-admin-api
      --web.config.file=/etc/prometheus/web_config/web-config.yaml
      --storage.tsdb.max-block-duration=2h
      --storage.tsdb.min-block-duration=2h
```
```


### Alertmanager version

_No response_

### Alertmanager configuration file

_No response_

### Logs

_No response_

comment.body: Not forgotten, just haven't got the time yet to dig into this further.

issue.title: Running out of disk space resulted in unrecoverable WAL error
issue.body:
### What did you do?

Ran Prometheus

### What did you expect to see?

Out-of-disk errors should cause temporary loss of data but not a fatal condition I have to log in and delete the WAL to fix.



### What did you see instead? Under which circumstances?

The disk filled up, and the first report of this was from the WAL:

```
ts=2023-10-23T23:11:06.646Z caller=scrape.go:1359 level=error component="scrape manager" scrape_pool=kube-system/cadvisor target=https://kubernetes.default.svc.cluster.local.:443/api/v1/nodes/gke-dev-redacted/proxy/metrics/cadvisor msg="Scrape commit failed" err="write to WAL: log samples: write /prometheus/data/wal/00006644: no space left on device"
ts=2023-10-23T23:11:06.704Z caller=scrape.go:1359 level=error component="scrape manager" scrape_pool=kubernetes-pods target=http://10.132.15.32:9150/metrics msg="Scrape commit failed" err="write to WAL: log samples: write /prometheus/data/wal/00006644: no space left on device"
...
ts=2023-10-23T23:11:08.474Z caller=scrape.go:1359 level=error component="scrape manager" scrape_pool=kube-system/kubelet target=https://kubernetes.default.svc.cluster.local.:443/api/v1/nodes/gke-dev-redacted/proxy/metrics msg="Scrape commit failed" err="write to WAL: log samples: write /prometheus/data/wal/00006644: no space left on device"
```

After this point apparently something was cleaned up on the disk (I didn't do it), because those errors stop.
Then remote-write reports it can't read that segment:
```
ts=2023-10-23T23:13:40.683Z caller=dedupe.go:112 component=remote level=error remote_name=some_remote_write url=https://example.com:1234/prometheus msg="error tailing WAL" err="segment 6644: unexpected full record: unexpected full record"
```

Now we get a flood of these, various ref numbers, presumably because those series were in the lost WAL segment:
```
ts=2023-10-23T23:14:06.048Z caller=dedupe.go:112 component=remote level=info remote_name=some_remote_write url=https://example.com:1234/prometheus msg="Dropped sample for series that was not explicitly dropped via relabelling" ref=56218783
```

Subsequently, the WAL cannot be truncated:
```
ts=2023-10-24T01:02:11.908Z caller=checkpoint.go:101 level=info component=tsdb msg="Creating checkpoint" from_segment=6625 to_segment=6656 mint=1698105600000
ts=2023-10-24T01:03:02.735Z caller=db.go:984 level=error component=tsdb msg="compaction failed" err="WAL truncation in Compact: create checkpoint: read segments: corruption in segment /prometheus/data/wal/00006644 at 61899498: unexpected full record"
```

This error repeats every 2 hours.  The WAL continues to grow.



### System information

Linux 5.15.107+ x86_64

### Prometheus version

```text
I built this Prometheus myself; it's a few commits on from 624b973eb.
```


### Prometheus configuration file

_No response_

### Alertmanager version

_No response_

### Alertmanager configuration file

_No response_

### Logs

```text
See log excerpts above.
```

comment.body:
I just experienced the same on v2.44.0. 

As per your 

> Out-of-disk errors should cause temporary loss of data but not a fatal condition I have to log in and delete the WAL to fix.

I actually would like to see a fatal condition where Prometheus exits or does become in an unhealthy state at the moment it fails to write. Having it run in this somewhat vague state is to me less desirable. I'd rather see it 'fail hard' then?

Especially in the case when we offload blocks (I.e. Thanos),  not being able to truncate the WAL eventually means we are going to miss out on the (then) longer term metrics because there are no blocks generated to ship. 

Also perhaps stating the obvious, but _just_ deleting the corrupted segment will then throw a:
```
caller=main.go:1155 level=error err="opening storage failed: get segment range: segments are not sequential"
```
which just (but please correct me if I'm wrong), no option other than to delete the WAL.

pull_request.title: promql: add sort_by_label and sort_by_label_desc functions
pull_request.body:
This adds functions to sort a vector by its label value.

Based on https://github.com/prometheus/prometheus/pull/1533

Signed-off-by: Alexander Trost <galexrt@googlemail.com>

***

There was some discussion around adding this functionality to PromQL/ Prometheus in the original PR #1533, though based on the various comments from users and now myself stumbling upon this while trying to visualize certain metrics sorted by label value, I would gladly see this topic revisited.
